results.title: The Pursuit of happiness
results.brief_description: Young sales hopefuls Tony and Mary introduce us to self-proclaimed success story Danny, the manager of a door-to-door distribution company. His business philosophy inspires a cult like zeal in his sales team, who battle the hurdles of the working day. Danny is a model and mentor, but is his belief in greed enough? The Pursuit of happiness offers great comic relief in its view of a world where the only measure of success is winning the daily dash for cash.

results.title: Puppenhead
results.brief_description: A Berlin puppet maker named Goethe takes his clockwork puppet knife-throwing act to New York. It is 1934 and a Nazi spy is watching him. A wickedly funny black comedy that quotes from Metropolis and Caligari, this short animation captures what was so good in German Expressionism- that eerie feeling of a world out of whack.

results.title: Picture start
results.brief_description: Making a film is only half the battle. Screening it is the other half, especially when there is a resistance from an unexpected quarter, eighth, sixteenth. The result is an amusing struggle with a particularly mischievous film leader. This engaging piece of genuine animation blends both computer generated and cell drawn material.

results.title: Nightride
results.creator_credit: Martin Murphy, Della Churchill and AFTRS
results.brief_description: A masked killer, a series of brutal murders, a confined space, a resourceful young hero and a terrifying confrontation. Nightride cleverly condenses the conventions of the horror film established in Halloween and Friday the 13th into a suspenseful 11 minute film.

results.title: Nice coloured girls
results.brief_description: Nice Coloured Girls contrasts the relationship between Australian First nations women and white men in the past and the present. The film juxtaposes contemporary images of black women taking advantage of a white man with voice over extracts from early journals of white settlers and sailors, in order to question the validity of conventional white history and to deny the image of First Nations people as passive and powerless.

results.title: My colour, your kind
results.brief_description: A young girl, incarcerated in a dormitory, escapes to her rightful place in the world. During the journey she recollects her life and the treatment she has endured. In My Colour, Your Kind director Danielle Mclean uses her experience as a fair skinned First Nations person to explore the notion of First Nations identity.

results.title: Morris loves Jack
results.brief_description: A star studded short drama, Morris Loves Jack is an off-beat romance between Jack, a young policewoman and Morris, the charming but feckless out of work actor who shares her house and her money. She is happy to support him emotionally and financially in spite of his irresponsible attitude to life until she finds him in the arms of another. Starring Kris McQuade and John Hargraves

results.title: Maidenhead
results.brief_description: Maidenhead is a series of chamber-fictions inhabited by a young woman named Alice. Linked in an oblique, dream like way, these short, sharp stories describe Alice’s survival in an everyday world of bizarre logic and strange emotions. It’s a place where miracles unfold in the bathroom and desire appears on a bus; where menacing joggers roam the suburbs and there’s something sinister about hats. Vibrant like musical, Maidenhead is at once funny and disquieting, poignant and absurd.

results.title: Lost
results.creator_credit: Jo Kennedy, Clare Sawyer and Ros Walker
results.brief_description: Three small children have been wandering a city beach. What begins as a seemingly routine case for detectives in Missing Persons becomes a puzzle. Twenty-four hours later no one has reported them missing and the police start to worry. Why can’t they locate their parents and why won’t the children speak?

results.title: Living room
results.brief_description: A catalogue of assorted Sydneysiders pose for the camera “at home”. A photographic mosaic of faces and places, Living Room exposes the myths surrounding home ownership and the shrinking potential of home ownership and reveals surprising values and attitudes. The program raises questions about the lack of services and isolation associated with outer suburban life. It looks at our treatment of the elderly and the way the nuclear family and the dream of “owning your own home” have shaped our living environment.
